review.title: Discriminative Predicate Path Mining for Fact Checking in Knowledge Graphs
review.abstract: Traditional fact checking by experts and analysts cannot keep pace with the volume of newly created information. It is important and necessary, therefore, to enhance our ability to computationally determine whether some statement of fact is true or false. We view this problem as a link-prediction task in a knowledge graph, and show that a new model of the top discriminative predicate paths is able to understand the meaning of some statement and accurately determine its veracity. We evaluate our approach by examining thousands of claims related to history, geography, biology, and politics using a public, million node knowledge graph extracted from Wikipedia and PubMedDB. Not only does our approach significantly outperform related models, we also find that the discriminative predicate path model is easily interpretable and provides sensible reasons for the final determination.

sections.heading: D. Fact Interpretation
sections.text: Although the discriminatory paths are used for fact-checking, there is no guarantee that all predicate paths will actually describe intuitive or important attributes of the given fact-finding. For example, the fact-finding-trained fact-checking model (Springfield, capitalOf, Illinois) includes many false 8 predicate paths such as < location − 1, location > and < deathPlace − 1, deathPlace >. These predicate paths indicate that "the capital is within the state" and that "a city is the place of death of a person who died in that state," which in their respective cases are accurate but not very descriptive of what capital city of actually means. Although these supportive predicate paths appear superfluous, they may in fact be used to identify false statements according to their learned regression weights. However, these false statements should probably not be contained in any "definition" of a given fact; instead, we want to distinguish these most important predicate terms from others that are merely human.

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: We introduced a fact check framework for knowledge graphs that discovers the definition of a given fact statement by extracting discriminatory predicate paths from the knowledge graph, and used the discovered model to validate the veracity of the given statement. To evaluate the proposed method, we verified the accuracy of several thousand statements about 8 different tasks on DBpedia and SemMedDB. We found that our framework was best in terms of fact checking performance all around and has a term similar to the existing models. We further tested the robustness of our algorithm by examining different ratios of true to false information and found that our framework was generally unchangeable for the class ratio.
